awd_titl_txt: High Precision Experiments to Study Light Neutral Meson Decay Rates and the Proton Charge Radius Using Electromagnetic Probes
awd_abstract_narration:
The award includes three projects at Jefferson Lab (JLab): (a) developing a new experiment to measure the proton charge radius with a sub-percent precision; (b) extracting the lifetime of the pi-zero meson with an unprecedented 1.4% precision from the PrimEx-II data set; and (c) developing and preparing the approved experiment to measure the lifetime of the eta meson in the newly developing Hall D.  As one of the most fundamental quantities, accurate knowledge of the proton size was always important in physics.  Very recently, a new result from a muonic-hydrogen experiment, with its unprecedented less than 0.1% precision, stated that the proton size is up to 7 standard deviations smaller than it was previously known to be.  This experimental fact triggered the well-known "proton radius crisis" in physics.  To address this crisis, a collaboration led by the PI of this award developed a uniquely designed electron-scattering experiment that was approved by PAC38 at JLab with the major condition of developing a new windowless gas hydrogen target.  Precision measurements of the light pseudo-scalar meson lifetimes continue to be an important part of this award.  The PrimEx collaboration performed the first measurement (PrimEx-I) of the pi-zero meson lifetime with the best precision up to date (2.8% in total).  The results have been published and included in the Particle Data Group average.  To reach the projected unprecedented 1.4% precision, our collaboration upgraded the experimental setup and performed the second (PrimEx-II) experiment in the fall of 2010.  Under this award, the analysis process will be completed, and the results published.  Under the leadership of the PI, a award to measure the eta meson lifetime with the best up to now precision (3%) was developed and approved to run in Hall D at JLab.  We will prepare this experiment to run for the next few years.

Precise knowledge of the proton size is critically important for understanding of the structure of hadronic matter.  In addition, it is very important for atomic physics, in particular, the spectroscopy of atomic hydrogen.  The currently developed experimental situation with the proton size limits the determination of the Rydberg constant, one of the basic and the most precisely known constant in physics up to now.  The proposed experiment, with its independent novel approach and projected precision, has a direct potential to either significantly shift the current value of the Rydberg constant (if it confirms recent muonic-hydrogen result) or question the sufficiency of the basic theory calculations in muonic-hydrogen system.  In the latter case, it may also indicate new physics beyond the Standard Model.  The lifetimes of the light pseudo-scalar mesons carry direct information about the symmetries, and in particular, their partial breaking effects in the theory of interaction in physics.  Therefore, the precise knowledge of these important quantities will serve as benchmark tests to our understanding of Nature.  In particular, the anticipated high precision measurement of the eta lifetime will significantly improve the ratio of light quark masses in a direct and most model independent way in physics.  The quark masses and their ratios are input into the contemporary particle physics from the experiment.  This project will provide advanced and highest scientific training for African-American students in a field where they are currently under-represented.

por.por_cntn:
Under this NSF award (PHY-125962) three major research projects have been carried out by our group: (a) a high precision extraction of the neutral pion life time; (b) the development of an experiment to measure the proton charge radius with a novel independent method and with a high precision to address the current ?proton radius puzzle? in our field of nuclear/particle physics; (c) the development of an experiment to measure one of the light neutral mesons (eta-meson) radiative decay width with a high precision.

The analysis processes for the first experiment (the PrimEx-II experiment at Jefferson Laboratory) was carried out under this award for the past several years. The neutral pion radiative decay width (the life time of this elementary particle) was successfully extracted during this year with an unprecedented 1.5% total uncertainty (see Fig.1).  The neutral pion is the lightest elementary particle consisting of other, more elementary parts (quarks), and its two-gamma decay channel is unique process that undergoing with a violation of one of the fundamental symmetries in Nature, the so-called left-right chiral symmetry. This violation, named as the ?Chiral Anomaly?, is possible only due to the quantum nature of the decay process and cannot be described with a classical physics approach.  Our new result, with its unprecedented accuracy, is proving the validity of the contemporary theory of elementary particles and interactions between them. The results of this experiment have already been presented at APS meetings and an international workshop. It is expected that this new result will have a significant impact on the Particle Data Group?s averaging on this important quantity.

The proton radius ?puzzle? is an effect of a significant disagreement of measurements performed in recent years using two different ?probing? particles: electrons and their heavier partners, the muons. The current situation in this field is such that if the upcoming new experiments prove the existing ?disagreement? then that potentially may indicate a ?new physics? beyond the currently well-established Standard Model in Physics.  The other experimental outcome will make our knowledge on this important quantity more accurate and possibly shifted by the amount of few percent. This will have a similar effect on the value of another more fundamental and the most accurately measured constant in physics: the so-called Rydberg constant in theory of hydrogen. Under this award we developed and conducted a new electron-proton scattering experiment at Jefferson Laboratory implementing a magnetic spectrometer-free method ?

a calorimetric method and normalizing the experimental outcomes to a well-known, pure electromagnetic electron-electron scattering process. These two experimental innovations are applied for the first time in electron proton scattering experiments, and they proved to be the best control of the systematic uncertainties in this type of experiments.  We are (the PRad collaboration) currently analyzing the accumulated rich experimental data set and have already released our preliminary results on the extracted structure functions (the so-called electric form factor) of the proton at extremely low momentum transfers (see Fig. 2). The final result on the proton charge radius is planned to be released before the spring of 2019.

This award was also critical for supporting graduate and undergraduate students research training in our Experimental Nuclear Physics group. Five graduate students completed their MS. Degree projects under this award. More than six undergraduate students had a chance to be trained in research under this award. Many of them are from underrepresented group of students in experimental nuclear physics or female. With that, this award had significant contributions in creation of highly trained professionals for our academia and industry.
